Organization.Name: *UC Berkeley Public Service Center*
Organization.Summary: UC Berkeley Public Service Center engages the University and the community in reciprocal partnerships to foster social justice and civic engagement.
Organization.Description:
Founded by students in 1967 as Cal Corps, the UC Berkeley Public Service Center partners with the community, student leaders and faculty to engage over 4,000 students each year as volunteers, and through jobs, internships, and courses.

The UC Berkeley Public Service Center connects ideas, resources, and people to act for social justice, build healthy communities, and foster life-long commitments to public service.

Organization.Name: 100 College Black Men, Berkeley Campus
Organization.Summary: To establish a solid network of Black men by fostering solidarity amongst ourselves through outreach to our commmunity that enhances educational and economic opportunities for all African Americans

Organization.Name: Aesthetics at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: To encourage and foster a community supporting the artistry and passion of bodybuilding held among UC Berkeley students.
Organization.Description:
“Every block of stone has a statue inside it and it is the task of the sculptor to discover it” - Michelangelo

What is art but simply a physical manifestation of grace and creativity sourced from the mind of its creator. Nothing is as immediate to an artist’s mind as the body itself. This direct relationship offers an absolute means of access to a medium possessed by all. Bodybuilding utilizes this relationship with the intent of creating a masterpiece unique to each artist capable of committing to the craft.

Organization.Summary: The mission of Premed AMSA is to develop professionalism and activism in our members as physicians-in-training. We aim to prepare students for medical school by providing resources, support, and leadership development. As activists, we seek to educate
Organization.Description:
The mission of Premed AMSA is to develop professionalism and activism in our members as physicians-in-training. We aim to prepare students for medical school by providing resources, support, and leadership development. As activists, we seek to educate premedical students about public health issues and advocacy, such as health policy, the culture of medicine, global health and preventative medicine. We believe that a comprehensive medical education is necessary for the development of every physician.

Our general meetings for Fall 2013 are held on Thursdays from 7-8 PM in 2063 VLSB. For more information, visit our website, amsa.berkeley.edu

Organization.Name: Berkeley American Civil Liberties Union
Organization.Summary: Berkeley ACLU is the college chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union. The ACLU advocates individual rights and liberties by by litigating, legislating, and informing.
Organization.Description:
Berkeley ACLU is the college chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union.

The ACLU's stated mission is to to defend and preserve the individual rights and liberties guaranteed to every person in this country by the Constitution and laws of the United States. It is the nation's largest non-profit law firm and one of the leading activist organizations. Some of the ACLU's most famous legal battles include the Scopes Evolution Trial of 1925, Japanese-American internment during WWII, the desegregation struggle of the Civil Rights era, contemporary women's reproductive rights, and numerous free speech issues.

Our organization was established in the Fall of 2000. We work to educate the campus community and promote civil liberties through film screenings, speaker panels, letter writing campaigns, and ASUC Senate resolutions.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Bahai Club
Organization.Summary: tbd
Organization.Description:
The Bahá’í Faith is a world religion based on the teachings of Bahá’u’lláh. He explained that there is only one God and one human family, and that all religions are spiritually united. Bahá’u’lláh’s writings offer spiritual guidance as well as directives for personal and social conduct.

The more than five million Bahá’ís around the world are engaged in the process of learning how to translate that guidance into realities of individual and community life. Though they come from diverse ethnic and cultural backgrounds, they are united by their belief in Bahá’u’lláh and by their desire for a united, prosperous, and peaceful future for all of humanity."

The Berkeley Baha'i Club upholds the standards of the Faith and aims to set ablaze love and unity for all of mankind. 

We encourage all of you who are interested to get in contact with us if you'd like to come to a meeting or an event or would just like to investigate the Faith.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Ballroom Dancers
Organization.Summary: Berkeley Ballroom is a student run group that has been providing classes, practices, and ballroom events for dancers in the Berkeley and East Bay area for the past 50 years!
Organization.Description:
Berkeley Ballroom is a student run group that has been providing classes, practices, and ballroom events for dancers in the Berkeley area for the past 50 years!

We cater to the needs of all dancers, and cater our classes to beginner social dancers. The best part is, for all of our events, no partner or experience is required, but if you have one or the other or both, that’s great, too!

Check UCBD.org for more information!

And ucbd.smugmug.com for pictures!

Organization.Name: Berkeley Bhangra Club
Organization.Summary: Berkeley Bhangra Club is an organization where students become aware of the aspects of the Bhangra folk art through structured Bhangra performances and organizing the west coast's premier bhangra competition, Dhol Di Awaz.
Organization.Description: Berkeley Bhangra Club is an organization where students will become aware of all the aspects of the Bhangra folk art. Through the classes and structured Bhangra performances, interested students will be able to learn and showcase their knowledge of Punjabi culture. Our primary focus will be on artistic aspects of choreography and music of Bhangra.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Business Society
Organization.Summary: Here at the Berkeley Business Society, our primary goal is to use BBS' extensive network to help members access a bank of internships, mentorships, and networking opportunities while gaining real-world experience and building their professional skills.
Organization.Description:
Here at the Berkeley Business Society, our primary goal is to use BBS' extensive network to help members access a bank of internships, mentorships, and networking opportunities while gaining real-world experience and building their professional skills. What sets BBS apart is that we take a personal approach and tailor the club experience to every individual. Our distinct committees--Consulting, Marketing, Finance, Professional Development, Pro-Bono Consulting, Information Technology, Entrepreneurship and Communications--encompass different sectors of business, and members can apply to be in the division that interests them. Furthermore, bi-weekly workshops present skills and opportunities that can be used in any field of business. It is our hope that in BBS you will be able to find an area of business that interests you, and from there we will do our best to help you reach success.

Mission

The Berkeley Business Society is a close-knit group that aims to develop three things in its members: Skills, Cohesion and Networking. Therefore, all of our activities are geared toward improving the business and analytical skills of our members, expanding the members' professional networks and building up strong cords of friendship within the group.

(Berkeley Business Society changed its name from IABC August 2013)

Organization.Name: Berkeley Cambodian Students Association
Organization.Summary: The Berkeley Cambodian Student Association was originally founded to unite and support people who share an interest in Cambodia and Cambodian culture by fostering an appreciation of that culture. Over the years, the Berkeley Cambodian Student
Organization.Description:
The Berkeley Cambodian Student Association was originally founded to unite and support people who share an interest in Cambodia and Cambodian culture by fostering an appreciation of that culture.

Over the years, the Berkeley Cambodian Student Association has evolved to place greater emphasis upon recognizing and sharing the Cambodian-American experience with the UC Berkeley community. The Cambodian-American story is neither a relic of the past nor an inert fact of today. Thus, the Berkeley Cambodian Student Association aims to reclaim Cambodian cultural and political histories, create socially aware individuals, inspire leadership and service, and bridge generations. We aim to eliminate the invisibility of the Cambodian-American community and empower its members.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Energy and Resources Collaborative
Organization.Summary: BERC is a multidisciplinary network of UC Berkeley students, alumni, faculty, industry professionals, and advisors who seek to turn world-leading research into world-changing solutions by tackling tough and timely energy and environmental challenges.
Organization.Description:
The Berkeley Energy & Resources Collaborative (BERC) is a multidisciplinary network of UC Berkeley students, alumni, faculty, industry professionals, and advisors who seek to turn world-leading research into world-changing solutions by tackling tough and timely energy and environmental challenges.

More specifically, BERC’s mission is to connect, educate, and engage its members in order to foster innovation and action. To that end, BERC:

  • Connects nearly 3,000 members as a part of a broad, cross-disciplinary network of students, faculty and professionals in the fields of energy and resources;
  • Educates students about cutting edge work in energy and resources through organizing events, lectures, and treks; and
  • Engages members by providing opportunities to address global energy and resources issues and collaborate on real-world projects.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Organization for Animal Advocacy
Organization.Summary: BOAA is an ASUC-sponsored student organization on the UC Berkeley campus. We have weekly meetings to discuss animal rights issues, plan events to advocate for animals, and enjoy yummy vegan food!
Organization.Description: The Berkeley Organization for Animal Advocacy is the campus' only social justice group dedicated to raising awareness about issues of animal oppression. We, at BOAA, firmly stand against the abusive, gendered, and exploitative nature of the treatment of animals in our society. We believe that the ills of factory farming are felt not only by non-human animals, but also by the environment, people of color, low income people, and the health and culture of our society. As a group, we are dedicated to raising awareness and promoting compassionate, socially just, and sustainable diets, and advocating for the liberation of animals from systems of human oppression. We participate in vegan and vegetarian outreach on campus and work in partnership with other local animal rights groups to better the lives of non-human animals.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Poetry Review
Organization.Summary: Berkeley Poetry Review (BPR) is the University of California, Berkeley's longest running poetry journal, having been published annually since 1974. It has earned the distinction of being one of the premier student-managed journals in the country.
Organization.Description:
Berkeley Poetry Review (BPR) is the University of California, Berkeley's longest running poetry journal, having been published annually since 1974. It has earned the distinction of being one of the premier student-managed journals in the country. Throughout the academic year, our staff works to produce a volume of poetry, with submissions coming from all accross the nation, as well as from students, faculty, and friends of the University. In addition, we wish to promote serious consideration of student creative writing and to foster a welcoming community where poets can hone their craft and receive helpful feedback about their work.

Past BPR issues have debuted the work of poets and writers such as Pablo Neruda, Vladimir Nabokov, John Ashbery, Lyn Hejinian, Brenda Hillman, Robert Hass, Lawrence Ferlinghetti, Charles Bukowski, Leslie Scalapino, Alfred Goldbarth, Luis Omar Salinas, Robert Pinsky, C.K. Williams, Billy Collins, Galway Kinnell, Mark Levine, Thom Gunn, Gary Soto, Ishmael Reed, Frederico Garcia Lorca, Victor Hernandez Cruz, Josephine Miles, Leonard Nathan, and many others.

Berkeley Poetry Review is distributed in bookstores and libraries nationwide, as well as online through Amazon and the American Book Exchange.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Political Review, The
Organization.Summary: UC Berkeley's only non-partisan political magazine.
Organization.Description:
Berkeley Political Review is UC Berkeley’s only nonpartisan political quarterly magazine. We publish and distribute the magazine for free four times a year (fall, winter, spring, and summer). Our staff is composed entirely of undergraduate students.

Berkeley Political Review meets every Tuesday at 7 pm, in North Gate Library. To learn more or to join our mailing list, please contact us at politicalreviewberkeley@gmail.com

Organization.Name: Berkeley Project, The
Organization.Summary: The Berkeley Project is among one of the largest volunteer organizations on the UC Berkeley campus. Every year, we host four large scale service events with over 3,000 volunteers at over 100 sites in the City of Berkeley and Greater East bay.
Organization.Description: The Berkeley Project began in 2006 as a one-day service event. We have since expanded Berkeley Project Day to an annual 2,000 person event where volunteers work on service project throughout the City of Berkeley. From working at elementary schools to planting trees, making meals for the homeless to helping out at senior centers, our volunteers devote 15,000+ hours every year. Sign up for the eighth annual Berkeley Project Day today!

Organization.Description: The Berkeley Review of Education (BRE) is a peer-reviewed interdisciplinary journal that engages issues of educational diversity and equity within cognitive, developmental, sociohistorical, linguistic, and cultural contexts. Published online and edited by students from the Graduate School of Education at the University of California, Berkeley, the BRE encourages submissions on research and theory from senior and emerging scholars, practitioners, and policymakers. BRE is an open access journal hosted by the eScholarship initiative of the California Digital Library, and will be published twice yearly.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Roots & Shoots
Organization.Summary: " Roots & Shoots is guided by the founding principles and extraordinary vision of Dr. Jane Goodall, renowned primatologist, environmentalist and humanitarian. Her firm belief that young people, when informed and empowered, when they realize that
Organization.Description:
"

Roots & Shoots is guided by the founding principles and extraordinary vision ofDr. Jane Goodall, renowned primatologist, environmentalist and humanitarian. Her firm belief that young people, when informed and empowered, when they realize that what they do truly makes a difference, can indeed change the world, is at the very heart of our program. This powerful message of hope inspires us all. Our program—dedicated to inspiring tomorrow's leaders today—not only motivates young people to learn about pertinent issues facing our local and global communities, but helps them actually design, lead and implement their own projects as a means of solving them."

- Roots and Shoots international website: http://www.rootsandshoots.org

Organization.Name: Berkeley Students for Life
Organization.Summary: Berkeley Students for Life (BSL) recognizes the inherent and inviolable dignity of human life. We are dedicated to working within our campus and local community to provide the resources necessary to make this happen.
Organization.Description:
Berkeley Students for Life: Mission Statement

As UC Berkeley’s pro-life student group, Berkeley Students for Life (BSL) recognizes the inherent and inviolable dignity of human life, from that of the unborn to that of the aged and terminally ill. We are dedicated to working within our campus and local community to put an end to abortion, embryonic stem cell research and euthanasia.

Since BSL is based at a prestigious educational institution, we see the need to educate our community about the truths surrounding offenses against human life. To that end, we facilitate and engage in intellectual discussion on relevant issues, challenging widely held relativist assumptions on the dignity of human life, the role of individual autonomy and society's role in protecting human life. Through these means, we seek to convince hearts and minds of the horrors of the offenses against life. We desire to convert society so that it might be more receptive to a culture of life that fully recognizes the dignity of every human being.

Furthermore, we aim to form leaders that will encourage the development of a more just society grounded in the recognition of the inherent and transcendent value of human life. We seek to enter our respective professions armed with the knowledge and tools needed to uphold the dignity of life in every facet of society.

Also at the heart of BSL’s mission is its commitment to community service. We believe that socioeconomic circumstances do not justify the taking of human life, and we affirm that such difficulties can be overcome. To that end, BSL provides information to assist women facing crisis pregnancies and refers them to local crisis pregnancy centers that provide women with what they need to bring new life into the world. We also volunteer at local crisis pregnancy centers to help promote their mission to encourage the bringing of new life into our community.

Though the focus of our outreach is primarily local, we collaborate with other pro-life organizations from around our state and nation and are united to them by virtue of our common cause. As a member of California Students for Life (CASTL), BSL is an active participant in the development of pro-life student activism at the state level. We also collaborate with Students for Life of America in order to engage in the fight for life at the national level. As an organization that concerns itself with matters of great public relevance, BSL strives to do everything in its capacity to shape public opinion on relevant university, state and federal policies, as well as to influence said policies, so that these might more accurately reflect our vision for a world in which every human life is valued and protected.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Undergraduate Sociology Association
Organization.Summary: tbd
Organization.Description:
The Berkeley Undergraduate Sociology Association (BUSA) is an organization of students who are interested in the field of sociology. BUSA organizes valuable academic, social, service, and sociological events for undergraduates by facilitating interaction between undergraduates, graduate students, and faculty. BUSA’s goal is to provide opportunities for sociology students to explore academic and service interests in a social setting while enriching their undergraduate experience.In the past few years, BUSA has organized the GSIology Series, BUSA Bowling, Honors Thesis 411 Session, Karaoke Night, ASA Conference participation, Alumni Night, and the groups’s premier annual event: The UC Berkeley Sociological Research Symposium.

If you are interested in joining this dynamic student group, please attend BUSA’s general meetings during the first week of each month in 475 Barrows Hall. Join us in creating a thriving, inclusive sociology community at Cal!

Or you can email us for more information at:  joinbusa@gmail.com

Organization.Summary: Berkeley Women in Business was founded by a group of dedicated and enthusiastic female Berkeley students hoping to pursue professional careers in business. The purpose of Berkeley Women in Business is to educate Cal women about contemporary issues in
Organization.Description: Berkeley Women in Business was founded by a group of dedicated and enthusiastic female Berkeley students hoping to pursue professional careers in business. The purpose of Berkeley Women in Business is to educate Cal women about contemporary issues in the business world, to create career-networking opportunities, and to learn about savings and investment as a means of developing financial independence. BWIB hosts several corporate events throughout the year in addition to helping our members with professional development.

Organization.Name: Cal Berkeley Democrats
Organization.Summary: The Cal Berkeley Democrats was founded in 1960 and is the official arm of the Democratic Party at the University of California, Berkeley.
Organization.Description: The Cal Berkeley Democrats was founded in 1960 and is the official arm of the Democratic Party at the University of California, Berkeley. We have a strong tradition of being involved in Democratic politics at both the local and state levels – our members have worked on city council races, presidential campaigns, and everything in between. We have the largest active membership of chapters among the California College Democrats. We are also one of the most active chapters of the California Young Democrats. In addition to working to get Democratic officials elected, our annual events include the California Democratic Party Convention, various community service projects, partaking in debates on-campus, and a variety of other social and professional events. The Cal Berkeley Democrats are committed to making the goals of the Democratic Party realities; these include but are not limited to – affordable higher education, good jobs with good pay, responsible environmental use, and affordable health care for every American. For more information about our club, including how you can get involved, please visit our website at www.caldems.com.

We accomplish this through workdays, fundraisers and events planned by our four committees:Special Events, Outreach & Advocacy, Publicity, and Media. We also run a decal every semester about issues in affordable housing. In addition, every semester we travel either nationally or internationally to build housing and create cross-cultural exchange.

Organization.Name: Gift to Life at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Our mission is to give hope and raise funds for the medical treatment of indigenous children in the world who suffer from plastic anemia as a result of pollution and environmental contamination caused my mining, oil drilling and pesticides. Our current
Organization.Description:
Our mission is to give hope and raise funds for the medical treatment of indigenous children in the world who suffer from plastic anemia as a result of pollution and environmental contamination caused my mining, oil drilling and pesticides. Our current target is Peru.
Plastic anemia is anemia that is characterized by defective function of the blood-forming organs (as the bone marrow) and is caused by toxic agents (as chemicals or X-rays) or is idiopathic in origin
Our specific aims include:

  • To provide funds for the DNA testing needed to find matching donors
  • To provide funds for blood transfusions for patients
  • To provide funds for bone marrow transplants
  • To engage corporate sponsors for the medical treatment of each child
  • To secure sponsorship for the education of the effected children following treatment
  • To raise awareness to people who live in contaminated environment

Organization.Name: Global Health Brigades at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: We are the UC Berkeley Chapter of the largest student-led global health volunteer organization in the world.
Organization.Description: Brigaders learn about current social, economic, and political issues in Latin America and how they are related to the health outcomes there. There is a DeCal course throughout the semester before participants go on a one or two week brigade to Honduras with the aim of providing access to healthcare, clean water, and basic sanitation infrastructure.

Organization.Name: Global Medical Training at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Global Medical Training is an international, non-profit, and humanitarian organization focused towards addressing the healthcare needs of developing countries in Latin America through providing free medical and dental care services.
Organization.Description: Global Medical Training (GMT) is an organization that is focused entirely around our motto "LEARN BY DOING." It gives students the unique chance to participate in a more "hands-on" diagnoses and treatments of patients in Latin America under the supervision and training given by medical professionals. In the process, students will not only have time to learn more about health related professions for their near future, but also be socially aware and culturally competent in order to aid other medical deprived nations. UC Berkeley students will be given a chance to expand their understanding of medicine as well as health related hardships of living in third world countries whilst increasing awareness of the lack of healthcare in such  countries and providing care, information for the betterment of the nation. GMT services are also not limited to our national partners but are provided to our community as well. We will offer our students the opportunity to volunteer in multiple service events focused towards serving the underprivileged community of Berkeley and beyond.

Organization.Name: Global Water Brigades at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: GWB is an international nonprofit organization with global health and sustainable development initiatives in developing countries.
Organization.Description: Our group offers Berkeley students the opportunity to volunteer in developing countries -- our most recent projects have been in Honduras where students worked in rural villages to improve access to clean water by developing a sustainable water infrastructure with community leaders. Many of our students are also Global Poverty and Practice minors and use their volunteer experience with GWB as part of the practice experience required for the minor.

Organization.Name: Hellenic Student Association at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: HSAB
Organization.Description: The goals of the Association are: 1. to bring together people of Hellenic heritage and people interested in Hellenic culture. 2. to organize and support cultural, social and recreational events for its members, affiliates and the Berkeley community in general. 3. to keep its members and the community informed about current issues on Greece, Cyprus and the European Union. 4. to promote the spirit of Hellenism. The Hellenic Student Association at Berkeley is not affiliated with any political parties.

Organization.Summary: The Hmong Student Association at Berkeley (HSAB) is a student-initiated service group with the mission to promote higher education and cultural understanding of the Hmong community.

Organization.Name: Iraqi Refugee Assistance Project at Berkeley Law
Organization.Summary: The Iraqi Refugee Assistance Project at Berkeley Law School is part of a national organization that uses a combination of direct legal aid and broad policy advocacy to develop and enforce a system of legal and human rights for Iraqi and Afghan refugees.
Organization.Description:
The Iraqi Refugee Assistance Project (IRAP) at Berkeley Law School is part of a national organization of 22 law schools and 49 global law firms in the Middle East, Canada, and the United States. We use a combination of direct legal aid and broad policy advocacy to develop and enforce a system of legal and human rights for Iraqi and Afghan refugees.

IRAP case teams take on urgent refugee cases that include: Iraqis and Afghans at risk of persecution because of their work as interpreters for the U.S. military; female survivors of sexual assault, domestic abuse, or human trafficking; and LGBT refugees. Law students are teamed up with attorney supervisors to provide free legal representation and services for the duration of the client’s resettlement application or appeals process.

IRAP’s policy team works directly with IRAP National to lobby the U.S. Congress. Our projects this year include lobbying Congress to extend the Special Immigrant Visa program, expand refugee programs for Afghans, and create comprehensive policy for LGBT refugees.

For more information, please contact May Whitaker, IRAP-Berkeley Chapter Director, or visit www.refugeerights.org

As
Organization.Description:
La Voz de Berkeley strives to voice the opinions, findings, and theories of those underrepresented by mainstream media. We want to address issues that affect our community, other people of color, and traditionally disenfranchised groups.

 

As Xican@/Latin@ students, we take the responsibility of questioning and challenging unfounded images that permeate mainstream media within and beyond campus. La Voz de Berkeley aims to provide an open space for expression and discussion about the social, cultural, economic, and political forces that affect our lives. ¡La Voz es tu voz!

 

Articles and images featured in our publication cover politics, art, and culture that reflect the diverse opinions of our own writers and artists. To help reach the extended community, we translate several articles that we believe are most relevant to our Spanish-speaking community.

Organization.Description:

Our mission is to raise awareness of the North Korean human rights crisis and fundraise to provide emergency relief and resettlement funds to North Korean refugees. All the money we raise goes to support  the underground shelters that run along the Chinese and North Korean border as well as other Southeast Asian countries that house North Korean refugees.

For more infomation see: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Liberty-in-North-Korea-UC-Berkeley-Rescue-Team/642353665799593

Organization.Name: Net Impact at Berkeley
Organization.ShortName: formerly Students for Responsible Business) (NI SRB
Organization.Summary: Net Impact is an international nonprofit organization with a mission to inspire, educate, and equip individuals to use the power of business to create a more socially and environmentally sustainable world. NIB is the Undergraduate chapter of
Organization.Description:
Net Impact is an international nonprofit organization with a mission to inspire, educate, and equip individuals to use the power of business to create a more socially and environmentally sustainable world.

NIB is the Undergraduate chapter of Net Impact. We are your link to a network of over 30,000 students and professionals, each of whom are interested in making a positive impact on the world. Our goal is to provide members with the real world experience and connections needed to excel and change the world.

We are sponsored by the ASUC, Haas School of Business, and the Center for Responsible Business. In addition, we work closely with other local Net Impact chapters (e.g., MBA at Haas, Professional at San Francisco, and other nearby universities) to provide our members with solid experience.

In short, NIB has four committees: Consulting, Marketing, Finance, and Internal Affairs. Each committee actively trains its associates so that our alumni are well-versed in each field. Our Consulting and Marketing Committees have their own process through which associates learn to strategize and develop successful campaigns. Our Finance Committee manages key relationships with corporations, and conducts on-site visits to learn more about the fast-paced world of finance. In Internal Affairs, associates learn how to plan events of various scales, as well as how to manage organizations. Please open the Committees tab to learn more about each committee.

As a general member, you will be able to attend all of our events, including many that are members-only. These events will prepare you to excel through networking and professional development. In addition, our general members are welcome to attend trainings hosted by any of our four committees.

In addition to our international sustainable development projects, our purpose is to engage students, serving as a medium to help students figure out our role in the ever-evolving world economy as we enter the workforce as global leaders in our respective professions.

Organization.Name: Undergraduate Journal of Psychology at Berkeley, The
Organization.Summary: Psychology at Berkeley is a biannual publication that allows undergraduate students who have completed scientific studies in psychology to disseminate their findings to the campus at large, thereby promoting excellence in and encouraging further
Organization.Description:
Psychology at Berkeley is a biannual publication that allows undergraduate students who have completed scientific studies in psychology to disseminate their findings to the campus at large, thereby promoting excellence in and encouraging further undergraduate research in psychology.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

CALL FOR UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH PAPERS

 

If you have completed a research paper in a psychology-related field, we invite you to submit your paper for publication in Psychology at Berkeley!

 

Psychology at Berkeley is a biannual publication that allows undergraduate students who have completed scientific studies in psychology to disseminate their findings to the campus at large, thereby promoting excellence in and encouraging further undergraduate research in psychology.

 

Psychology at Berkeley is currently accepting submissions for its fourth edition, to be published during the Fall 2010 semester.


Psychology at Berkeley accepts and reviews submissions from all psychology-related fields, as long as the papers are completed by undergraduate students; this includes senior honors theses, course term papers, independent research projects, theoretical papers, and all other excellent undergraduate writing. Multiple submissions are welcome.


To submit an original research article for review and publication:

  • Verify that your submission does not contain any identifying information (to ensure anonymity during the selection process), and attach a word or pdf copy of the article in an e-mail to berkpsychjournal@gmail.com.
  • Include your full name, paper title, telephone number, and preferred e-mail address in the body of your e-mail message
  • If you are a Berkeley student, please send your paper using your CalMail address and note in the body of your e-mail that you are a Berkeley student so that you will receive Cal student priority for publication

 

The deadline to submit papers is midnight on February 28, 2010. However, papers received earlier will have higher priority. Applicants will be notified by early March if their paper is being considered for publication.

 

If you have any questions about or difficulty in submitting your paper, please contact berkpsychjournal@gmail.com for further information. We look forward to reading your submissions!

({}) V-Day at UC Berkeley ({}) is not only a group that
Organization.Description:
Become a fan of V-Day at UC Berkeley on Facebook to get updates on ticket sales, events, opportunities to get involved, and of course, when and where the show will be in February!! 

 

({}) V-Day at UC Berkeley ({}) is not only a group that puts on playwright Eve Ensler's The Vagina Monologues every year to raise money to end violence against women, but we are a movement on campus and in our community. 
Every fall, we assemble a cast and crew through auditions to form a community for strong, motivated students who have, do or will identify as a woman. This community becomes a place of strength where women empower each other, learn from each other and prepare themselves to become a vagina warrior. 


Through alliances with other student groups and through the support of UC Berkeley's Gender Equity Resource Center and the ASUC, we strive to make this a learning experience not for those part of the movement but for all of those on campus. 


Every spring, as part of the culimination of our community and movement building, we bring our awareness and strength to the public through benefit performances of The Vagina Monologues to raise money and awareness to stop violence against women.

Our vision is to seek and raise up believers and to nurture a maturity amongst them that will transcend their college years. We
Organization.Description:
Crossroads Christian Fellowship is the college fellowship of Vinewood, the English ministry at Chinese for Christ (CFC) Church in Berkeley.

We are a student-led Christian fellowship on the Berkeley campus. We meet together on Friday nights at 7:30pm to worship, study the Word, and socialize with followers of Christ. We also offer weekly small groups to nurture personal spiritual growth in a more intimate setting. We are a ministry of Vinewood at Chinese for Christ Berkeley.  Our church is located two blocks past Ashby on Prince Street and College Avenue. 

Our vision is to seek and raise up believers and to nurture a maturity amongst them that will transcend their college years. We foster leadership opportunities so that members of our fellowship can develop their spiritual gifts and grow to become dependent on God alone by being challenged by the Word. CFC Berkeley also sponsors a young adult fellowship that offers spiritual mentors for college students.

Organization.Name: Entrepreneurial Society of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: ES renamed from FSES per ASUC Senate Bill 133 10-31-12
Organization.Description:
FSES, UC Berkeley's newest business club founded in 2010, was the result of an entrepreneurial passion shared by two friends and college entrepreneurs.  Arian Rezazadeh (Class of 2013) and Ethan Mark (Class of 2013) had a unique idea for the 2009 Cal vs. Stanford Big Game to help Cal fans show their team pride.  As Arian and Ethan always describe it, "It all started with a small idea for a big game, and it turned out to be a big idea for an even bigger game." Arian and Ethan designed Big Game t-shirt people went crazy for, marketed it on campus, and sold a significant quantity of them. But it didn't end there. This business venture that they created from scratch took a lot of time and work. This prompted them to seek a club on campus that could help them out, make the process easier, and allow them to have a support group. To their dismay, Arian and Ethan could not find any clubs on campus that could assist freshman and sophomore students in this, and so they co-founded FSES to meet the needs of this part of the student body.  

Today, FSES has rapidly grown into a premier business club focused on a niche of meeting the needs of freshman and sophomore students at the University of California, Berkeley to develop their ideas and make them into full-on business ventures that can operate as stand-alone businesses. With a speaker series of successful entrepreneurs, case studies of entrepreneurial ideas, the 'Best Entrepreneurial Idea of the Semester' competition, and legal assistance team for start-ups, FSES is the club you want to be a part of. It's practical knowledge, a support group, and a place where you can make your ideas a reality.

Organization.Description:
Global China Connection (GCC–å?¨ç??ä¸­å?½è??æ?¥) is the world's largest International-China student organization. GCC has developed chapters at top universities in the United States, Canada, England and China all working to promote cultural awareness and understanding, develop friendship and language exchange, as well as participate in philanthropic projects and community engagement; though most importantly, to develop a network of the top international talent of the 21st century. GCC is currently partnering with other networks and organizations including PKU's Student International Communication Association, US-China Exchange Association, Givology, China Institute, Weatherhead East Asian Institute, Peking Globalist, and many others, in an attempt to bring together the various resources and opportunities available to Chinese and Western students, in order to promote the common goals of sustainable development, social entrepreneurship, and international communication. For more information, please visit online at www.globalchinaconnection.com.

As a new chapter here at Cal, we are looking for a group of distinguished and capable students who are passionate about international affairs and business communications.
Each participant has the opportunity to improve leadership and management skills, gain technical and industry experience, and expand social and business networking.

Organization.Name: Historical Fencing Club of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The purpose of the Historical Fencing Club of Berkeley is to provide a study group for students of Classical and Historical fencing who are training in and/or researching any of the various forms of heritage/traditional or reconstructed Western
Organization.Description:
The purpose of the Historical Fencing Club of Berkeley is to provide a study group for students of Classical and Historical fencing who are training in and/or researching any of the various forms of heritage/traditional or reconstructed Western Martial Arts.  The group will give special attention to the pedagogy and practice of living lineages of traditional fencing as a basis for study.  The secondary goal of the group is to provide group members with a direct connection to the Classical fencing that existed in the early 20th and late 19th century in the Berkeley area. 

 

To achieve this, the Historical Fencing Club of Berkeley draws on the expertise of local and non-local Classical fencing masters and certified instructors as well as the support of dedicated students and scholars of Classical fencing and non-profit organizations such as the Association for Historical Fencing. 

 

The meetings of this organization will help Classical fencers find ways to train the techniques and theory of Classical fencing but who may not have access to regular classes or training partners in Berkeley.  Having training partners is essential to fencing, because fencing, like any martial art, is a kinesthetic art that requires movement, sensibility, and interaction with other human beings much the way partner dance does. 

 

Today, Classical fencing is a rare traditional martial art that is not widely practiced.  Practicing Classical fencing will help to preserve its theory and philosophy and ensure its survival alongside more widely available and practiced modern styles of fencing (i.e. “sport” or “Olympic” fencing) that have departed from the traditional way of thinking and practicing. 

 

What makes the Historical Fencing Club of Berkeley unique from other organizations is its focus on Classical theory in fencing, or fencing as a martial art, which treats training, bouting, academic assaults, etc. with the same respect and sincerity that good traditional fencing masters have always given to training for and participation in real combative encounters or duels.  This sort of training is contrasted with that of modern fencing which often trains to the rules of the sport or game of fencing as is defined by organizations such as the United States Fencing Association (USFA) and the Federation Internationale d’Escrime (FIE); the Historical Fencing Club of Berkeley recognizes “modern,” “sport,” “Olympic,” and other synonymous styles of fencing training as inappropriate and dangerous in the context of martial arts training.

The second way that HJB builds community is through the staff. They know each other well, and support each other not just in journal related issues, but in life.

Organization.Summary: ToxSA supports students in the Molecular Toxicology major and non-majors interested in the field of toxicology by providing peer advising, career preparation, and community service opportunities.
Organization.Description:
ToxSA supports students in the Molecular Toxicology major and non-majors
interested in the field of toxicology by providing peer advising, career
preparation, and community service opportunities as well as exploring past
and current issues in toxicology.

Peer Advising-
Our peer advising services allow students in the same classes to get
together and form study groups as well as allow upper class-man to talk
with the lower class-man to direct and guide them through the courses at
Berkeley.

Community Service
A program sponsored by ToxSA called the Lead Education Awareness Program
(LEAP) allows students to become involved with toxicology related
community service. LEAP is a program that allows students to educate
children in low-income areas about the dangers from household hazards,
lead, and air pollution.

Career Prep-
Our career preparation services support students by touring the career
center, holding a resume writing workshop, and holding brown bag lunches
with the professors in the Molecular Toxicology department at Berkeley. 
Members of ToxSA also become members of the NorCal Society of Toxicology
(SOT).  This service has given students the opportunity to talk with real
life toxicologists in the field and learn what day to day life is like in
different toxicology fields.

ToxSA supports students not only through their years at Berkeley, but also
helps them for the future by exploring careers and networking

Organization.Description:
*General meetings on Wednesday at 7 pm in 215 Dwinelle. Join us!

We at the World Literacy Project believe that literacy is the key to a better world. This year, we will be hosting two reading programs for elementary students in partnership with the Berkeley Public Library and John Muir Elementary School, working with local and international NGOs to raise literacy awareness and designing another literacy program that Cal students will implement abroad over Summer 2014.

Begun in 2010, WLP has demonstrated its commitment to service by initiating literacy programs, supporting 9 Cal students to build a school in Nicaragua, hosting a Global Child Issues Forum in partnership with several SF-based nonprofits, designing a computer literacy curriculum in Guatemala and more! We regularly educate ourselves on cost-effective poverty solutions during general meetings, and continually seek partnerships with NGOs and other student groups to promote activism on the three topics we care about the most: poverty alleviation, literacy, and gender equity.

Organization.Name: Bay Area Scientists in Schools at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: GA Bay Area Scientists in Schools
Organization.Description:
Program Goals

Bay Area Scientists in Schools (BASIS) is a science role model volunteer program for public elementary schools in the East Bay.

The goals of BASIS are to connect a diverse range of scientist volunteers to elementary and middle school students and teachers, to inspire students with examples of real-world science careers and issues, to engage students in hands-on, inquiry based learning experiences, and to create effective teaching links between scientists and public elementary schools.

Program Mechanics

Community Resources for Science (CRS) works with BASIS volunteers to help develop hands-on activities that are age-appropriate and based in the California Science Standards. Scientists then select dates and times that they are available to visit classrooms to make lesson presentations, and teachers are invited to sign up for presentations as they become available. "Tremendous! More, please!" is the top comment CRS hears from teachers who've had a BASIS visit.

Scientists may work solo or in teams to develop a presentation to take to multiple classrooms over the course of a school year.

Berkeley Forum, The
Organization.Summary: The Berkeley Forum is a non-partisan forum for the expression and debate of a wide range of ideas. Founded in 2012, the Forum organizes panels, debates, and talks by leading experts and distinguished persons on issues both topical and timeless.
Organization.Description:
The Berkeley Forum is a non-partisan forum for the expression and debate of a wide range of ideas. Founded in 2012, the Forum organizes panels, debates, and talks by leading experts and distinguished persons on issues both topical and timeless. Forum events are open to the public and will be broadcast online.

The Forum is run entirely by undergraduate students at the University of California, Berkeley, though it is advised by a committee of distinguished professors. Berkeley Forum members are motivated, intellectually curious students from a diverse range of academic and professional backgrounds. The Forum provides students valuable first-hand experience and a channel to explore and challenge the ideas that motivate them.

Our Organization

The guiding authority of the Forum rests in the president and an executive committee, composed of the president and two vice presidents. The president and executive committee of the Forum are responsible for the day-to-day operations, the long-term growth, and ultimate success of the Forum.

Forum operations are carried out by two standing committees, each of which is chaired by a vice president. Each standing committee plays a central role in the planning and realization of Forum events. A programming affairs committee recruits guest speakers, handles travel and accommodation arrangements, and creates the program for Forum events. A communications committee publicizes all Forum events and serves as curator of the organizationâ€™s brand and graphic standards. The president may from time-to-time, with the advice and consent of the executive committee, form special committees.

The Forum also houses a systems and technology division, in charge of web design and other technology-related tasks, a development division, in charge of fundraising, and an external affairs division, which oversees membership recruiting and outreach efforts. Each division is overseen by a director.

Our Mission

The mission of the Berkeley Forum is to provide the Berkeley community a non-partisan forum for the presentation and debate of a wide range of ideas; to reaffirm the value of a liberal arts education; and to regularly organize, promote, and broadcast debates, panels, and talks by distinguished persons, and any such events, activities, or conversations as shall engage and challenge the faculties of the mind.

Admission to Forum events

Admission to Forum Events is free for all members of the Forum and persons affiliated with the University of California, Berkeley. This includes students, professors, administrators, and other staff members.

A fee of $5 (as of March 2013) will be required of all other event attendees and will be collected at the event, unless otherwise noted.

Organization.Name: CA Bikes International at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: ASUC Sponsored per SB 27 Sp 12 2/20/13
Organization.Description:
Who Are We?

CA Bikes International at Berkeley is a new student group working to support Chris Ategeka's non-profit organization, CA Bikes International. CA Bikes International is an established nonprofit which works on the ground in Uganda making bicycles, wheel chairs, and bicycle ambulances. It is a Green organization, in that all of these products are made from recycled materials. The goal of this non-profit is to aid the chronic poverty in Uganda by working to provide its citizens with mobility, in order to facilitate their access to education and healthcare. They also helps to create local employment and entrepreneurs by giving them the mobility to start businesses.

Some statistics about what they have already helped to achieve:

There are currently 10 bicycle ambulances in Uganda, which serve 1,000 people every month. One bicycle ambulance serves anywhere between 75 to 100 people in one month. CA Bikes has already been sponsored by Chevron, Zambikes, The United States Embassy- Uganda, Judith Lee Stronach and Big Ideas at Berkeley.

Organization.Name: Capital Investments at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Capital Investments at Berkeley is a student-run initiative that aims to educate UC Berkeley students on necessary skills for trading investment products.
Organization.Description:
Capital Investments at Berkeley Constitution and Bylaws

04/14/2012 Amended

 

Date Approved (Center for Student Leadership staff): 02/05/13

Approved by (Center for Student Leadership staff): Stephanie Chan

 

ARTICLE I – Name

 

Section 1. The name of the organization shall be “Capital Investments at Berkeley”, hereafter referred to as CIB.

 

Section 2. The Executive Board of CIB, hereafter referred as the ‘Executive Board,’ shall be made up of one President, the Vice President of Portfolio Management, the Vice President of Operations and the Vice President of Investment Research. Officer positions shall be created as deemed necessary by the Executive Board.

 

Section 3. The Alumni Advisor is a founder of CIB and serves as a consultant, and is only involved in the major decision-making and approval processes.

 

ARTICLE II –Purpose

 

Capital Investments at Berkeley is a student-run initiative that aims to educate UC Berkeley students on necessary skills for trading alternative investment products. Through our capital investments fund (CIB fund), students will gain first-hand experience in exploring and executing various trading strategies. Meanwhile, we also seek to deliver long term and consistent absolute returns.

 

The CIB fund is a student investment fund which pools money from investors at UC Berkeley and other universities. Officers and the Executive Board members are responsible for managing the portfolio and following the requirements strictly set by the investment mandate, liability waivers and prospectus of the CIB fund.

 

ARTICLE III – Membership

 

Section 1. Only currently registered students, faculty and staff may be active members in CIB. Members are allowed to participate in general meetings and events organized by the officers of CIB. CIB will take members’ advice into consideration. However, members do have not voting power in the decision making process of managing the CIB fund. Only active members may vote or hold office. SC

 

Section 2. CIB considers hazing to be a degrading and destructive activity, which is inconsistent with the standards of this student organization. We will strictly abide by relevant California State laws. CIB recognizes the dignity of every person and opposes all forms of hazing. We will not haze according to California State Law. SC

 

Section 3. We will not restrict membership based upon race, color, national origin, religion, sex, physical and mental disability, medical condition (cancer-related or genetic characteristics), ancestry, marital status, age, sexual orientation, citizenship or status as a covered veteran (special disabled veteran, Vietnam-era veteran or any other veteran who served on active duty during a war or in a campaign or expedition for which a campaign badge has been authorized). SC

 

ARTICLE IV - Analysts/Officers/Appointment

 

Section 1. Analyst

 

At the beginning of each semester, the Executive Board shall recruit analysts. The Executive Board will design a training program to equip analysts will the necessary skills to serve the purpose of CIB, which is to educate members on trading various financial products and to manage the CIB fund in a professional manner.

 

The Executive Board shall conduct at least a 20 minute interview with each potential candidate for the analyst program. The Executive Board will identify the most suitable candidate to become analysts. The appointment must be confirmed by the President and the Alumni Advisor will be notified.

 

Section 2. Officers

 

CIB shall have the following Executive Board members, which shall be nominated by the members of the current Executive Board and appointed by the President of Capital Investments at Berkeley:

 

The President shall preside over all meetings of CIB, shall be an ex-officio member of all committees established by the Board, and shall have the power to appoint members to such committees, as the Board shall establish. The President shall be responsible for the overall activities of CIB and shall represent CIB in all official matters, unless he or she chooses to delegate the above duties. Furthermore, in all meetings of the Board and of all other Committees created by the Board, the President, has the right to make final decisions regarding all matters of CIB with support from the Alumni Advisor.

 

The Alumni Advisor is the founder of CIB, and is an alumnus of UC Berkeley. He is not involved in the daily operations of CIB. He is also not involved in most of the decision making process of the CIB fund. He is only responsible for the final approvals after the Executive Board members and gives advice.

 

The Vice Presidents shall assume such duties delegated to them by the President. In the event of the President's absence, disability, or resignation, the Vice Presidents shall assume the duties of the President in the manner provided under Article IV section 5.

 

The Vice President of Operations shall have charge of internal functions, manage external contacts, establish and maintain good public relationships, mediate members’ concerns, and oversight of financial affairs of CIB.

 

The Vice President of Investment Research shall have charge of deriving innovative and practical investment strategies, as well as equity and securities research.

 

The Vice President of Portfolio Management is responsible for monitoring risks and returns of the portfolio, and makes trade decisions with the approval of the President and Alumni Advisor. The Vice Presidents and officers execute trades with the President’s approval.

 

The Vice President of Administrations shall have charge of the general records and correspondence of the CIB, shall take attendance, and shall prepare written minutes of all meetings of the Board and of all meetings of the general membership. Furthermore, the Vice President of Administrations shall have charge of the financial records and make them available for inspection to any member of the Board or general membership when requested.

 

All Officers shall be active members of CIB, and have joined the analyst program in the past.

 

To become an officer, he or she must join the analyst program organized by the Executive Board and current officers. The program consists of training that is essential to become the portfolio managers of the CIB fund.

 

Section 3. Appointment

The Executive Board members shall conduct an appointment meeting at least two weeks before the end of each academic semester.

 

Any analyst of CIB who joined the training program at the beginning of the semester is eligible to be nominated.

 

Discussion will be conducted between members of the Executive Board and final decision will be made by the President and approved by the Alumni Advisor and the President.

 

The President shall supervise all nomination and appointment procedures.

 

Section 4. Removal of Officers

 

Any officer may be removed according to the following procedure. Upon the submission to any officer of CIB of a written petition, the President shall call a special meeting of the Executive Board of CIB. An officer can be removed by the two third members of the Executive Board and final approval by the President and Alumni Advisor.

 

Section 5. Vacancies in Office

 

Upon the President's temporary absence or disability, the Vice President of Operations shall share the appropriate duties and responsibilities of the President's functions during such temporary period.

 

Upon the President's permanent absence through resignation or other cause, the Vice Presidents may decide between themselves who shall assume the functions of the President. In the event that there can be no agreement between them, the final decision will be made the Alumni Advisor.

 

Upon the permanent absence of any other Officer through any cause, the President shall decide to whether to appoint a new officer. All vacancies are to be filled within two weeks of the opening of the vacancy. Upon appointment, the replacement shall immediately assume the functions of such officer, subject to ratification by a majority of the members of CIB attending the next validly convened general meeting.

 

Any officer must present in writing a formal statement of his or her resignation at least two weeks prior to the date of his or her resignation.

 

Upon the permanent absence of any officer through any cause, the Executive Board should conduct an internal meeting and decide whether to include a new officer.

 

ARTICLE V - Meetings

 

Section 1. General Meetings of CIB shall be open to all members and be conducted at least twice per year. Any member may attend the General Meetings of CIB.

 

Section 2. Vice President of Operations should contact all members regarding the time and locations of the General Meetings, either through mail, phone calls or emails, unless he or she delegates this duty to an officer.

 

Section 3. An analyst meeting shall be conducted each week. The Executive Board and current officers will provide essential training for the analysts in order to them to be successful officers in the future.

 

Section 4. An officer meeting shall be conducted weekly. Officers and the Executive Board will discus the portfolio held by the CIB fund and make investment suggestions and handle other administrative issues.

 

ARTICLE VI - Constitutional Amendments

 

Section 1. A meeting to amend the provisions of this Constitution shall be convened by the officers and agreed by the Executive Board, and be finally approved by the President and Alumni Advisor.

 

Section 2. All amendments, additions or deletions must be filed with the Center for Student Leadership in 102 Hearst Gym within one week of adoption. SC

 

ARTICLE VII – Dissolution

 

Section 1. CIB may be dissolved at any time with the approval of all the Officers and the Alumni Advisor.

 

Section 2. All unspent ASUC funds shall remain the property of the ASUC, all Graduate Assembly funds shall remain the property of the Graduate Assembly. Remaining privately obtained funds may be donated to another nonprofit organization with prior approval of the ASUC Senate Finance Committee. Investment funds from investors must be returned to investors.

 

A Bill In Support of Capital Investments at Berkeley

4/3/2013

 Authored by Senator Daley Vertiz and Monica Ruiz

Sponsored by Senator Daley Vertiz


WHEREAS, Capital Investments at Berkeley (CIB) was founded in 2011 to allow UC Berkeley students to learn about the markets through real experience; and,


WHEREAS, there are a lack of campus organizations that teach students about the financial world in an in-depth manner; and,


WHEREAS,CIB aims to provide consistent returns with minimal risk exposure through utilizing equities, derivatives and alternative investment products; and,


WHEREAS, By managing an actual money fund comprised of investments from club members and external investors, club members make real decisions to achieve real growth; and,


WHEREAS, CIB’s mission is to increase financial awareness and knowledge in the student body through its analyst training program, a semester-long crash course in trading that exposes analysts to most of the financial instruments including securities, options, and bonds; and,


WHEREAS, CIB hosts weekly conference calls to discuss market trends and predictions; and,


WHEREAS, CIB also develops members professionally byhosting corporate sponsors to assist with recruitment and to educate students about careers/career planning in the finance industry; and,


THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED, the ASUC recognizes Capital Investments at Berkeley (CIB) as a 1st year ASUC Sponsored Student Activity Group (SAG).

Our goal is to offer guidance and role models as students consider pursuing careers in healthcare and then actively support them as they navigate through their professional training years and into a life of serving the Lord in a healthcare career by going on medical missions to underserved countries abroad and within the States

By encouraging university officials and stakeholders, both of whom are large purchasers of electronics and powerful spokespersons, to commit to measures that pressure electronics companies to responsibly invest in Congo's minerals sector, we can voice our demand for conflict-free products from Congo. Comprehensive reform is needed in Congo to bring about sustainable peace- now is the time is now for students to lead the conflict-free movement for peace in eastern Congo.

Organization.Description: Edge Interns is unique in that it is not restricted to one industry, ethnic group, or major, but is focused on the exploration and expansion of its members' development through personalized mentoring, exclusive industry internships, and professional networking. Organization.Name: Embrace- The Berkeley Chapter
Organization.Summary: Embrace is a social enterprise that aims to help the millions of vulnerable babies born every year in developing countries through a low cost infant warmer.
Organization.Description: Embrace is a social enterprise that aims to help the millions of vulnerable babies born every year in developing countries through a low cost infant warmer. Unlike traditional incubators that cost up to $20,000, the Embrace Infant Warmer costs less than 1% of this price. The device does not require constant electricity, is portable and is safe and intuitive to use. This spring, Embrace will be launching in the state of Karnataka, India. Embrace- the Berkeley Chapter seeks to promote and advance the efforts of Embrace via fundraising and awareness activities.

Organization.Name: Engineering and Business Society of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Engineering and Business Society of Berkeley (EBSB) is a professional and scientific society whose purpose shall be helping student to explore the intersection of different fields of engineering and business.
Organization.Description:
The purpose of the Organization shall be providing a knowledge platform at Berkeley that integrate scientific foundations of business and engineering; and a resource for engineering and business students to develop professional skills and learn about possible career opportunities that bridge different fields of business and engineering. 

An engineer needs to obtain the business skills and knowledge required to make his or her entrepreneurial vision a reality. Engineering graduates at UC Berkeley need to learn how to lead both the business aspect and the technological aspect of a successful enterprise. UC Berkeley provides two of the best academic program at the College of Engineering and the Haas School of Business. Engineering and Business Society of Berkeley (EBSB) will bridge the gap between these two parts of UC Berkeley and bring undergraduates from both schools together under one platform.

Organization.Name: Free Racquet Club at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Our purpose is to provide tennis coaching and equipment to youth aged 5-17 in the Berkeley area.
Organization.Description: Our proposed organization is different from existing tennis clubs at UC Berkeley because it targets underprivileged youth (ages 5-17) and not college students in the Berkeley area. Youth that demonstrate financial need can sign up for access to weekly lessons and equipment. Our club will provide a unique volunteer experience for Berkeley students interested in sharing their tennis talent with youth who normally wouldn't have access to coaching. Berkeley students that don't play tennis but are still interested in our cause are also welcome to aid in facilitation of practices and purchasing drinks and snacks for the kids.

Organization.Name: French Association of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The French Association of Berkeley aspires to promote French and francophone culture at UC Berkeley through a melange of film screenings, performing and visual arts shows, as well as popular culture.
Organization.Description: We organize short talks and discussions about French culture (book reviews, films, plays), academic and scholarly events based on French current events and news. Anyone fascinated by French culture and keen on improving their French colloquial skills is welcome to join our social meetings, our French food contests and degustations or our French language group sessions, not to mention our annual Bastille Day gathering!

Organization.Name: Givology at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The purpose of this group is to fundraise and build awareness for education projects in third-world countries and partner with international non-profits to facilitate these transactions in other nations.
Organization.Description: The purpose of this group is to fundraise and build awareness for education projects in third-world countries and partner with international non-profits to facilitate these transactions in other nations.

Organization.Name: Go Game at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: We aim to gather students at Berkeley who are passionate about Go Game and want to find people of the same interest. We aim to introduce Go to people and the Chinese culture behind it. This is a great comfort zone for all Go players.
Organization.Description: GO is a Chinese traditional board-game, which is a kind of miniature of two rival militaries racing to control more territories. Playing GO improves your skills like crisis management, critical thinking, tactics, etc. It is a both intellectual and fun game.

Organization.Name: Golfers' Association of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The mission of Golfers' Association of Berkeley is to promote friendly competition amongst golfers at Cal, teach the game to aspiring golfers, and encourage a love for golf.
Organization.Description: This organization is unique from the one other existing golf related organization on campus because it is an outlet for both competitive golfers and a platform for aspiring golfers to receive coaching. The leaders of this club are advanced and passionate enough players to teach beginners the game of golf, and the tournaments we host will allow the numerous low-handicap golfers at Cal to compete on a level that they may not have the resources to engage in.

Organization.Name: Grant a Wish at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: to help support local organizations that aim to grant the wishes of exceptionally special children that have fallen under special circumstances.
Organization.Description: The purpose of our club is to help support local organizations that aim to grant the wishes of exceptionally special children that have fallen under special circumstances. Our club will help Berkeley students and people in the Berkeley community connect with and support these local groups. People within our club will help in wish granting, fundraising, and assisting in special events. Our main goal is to help make life-changing impacts on children, families, donors, sponsors- the entire community.

Organization.Name: He Intends Victory at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: To educate the Christian community by providing educational packets, examples of church policy and personal testimony of Christians living with HIV/AIDS. To provide a loving Christian witness and scriptural literature at HIV/AIDS meetings
Organization.Description: To encourage a spiritual awakening within the HIV/AIDS community, and to promote faith in Jesus Christ as a living and personal God. To support churches in outreach opportunities to their HIV/AIDS members, their families and the local community. To educate the Christian community by providing educational packets, examples of church policy and personal testimony of Christians living with HIV/AIDS. To provide a loving Christian witness and scriptural literature at HIV/AIDS meetings and conferences nationally and internationally.

Organization.Name: Health Professional Student Alliance at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Health Professional Student Alliance at Berkeley aims to cultivate leadership and advocacy skills among health professional students.
Organization.Description: The goal is to effect change in the health care system, primarily through grassroots efforts, education and chapter growth, in support of comprehensive, publicly-financed, privately-delivered guaranteed healthcare for all Californians.

Organization.Name: Irish Dancers of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: We aim to provide a time, place, and platform for Irish dancers of all experience levels to practice, perform, and explore all aspects of Irish dance, while bringing a bit of craic to Cal!
Organization.Description:
For many college-aged Irish dancers, it is difficult to continue participating in this cultural art form and sport for several reasons. When they move away from their dance company, they do not have space to practice, they do not have the same incentive of teamwork and camaraderie that is so central to the activity, and they do not have the chance to perform. 

The Irish Dancers of Berkeley does regular stamina and technique workouts, but we also choreograph traditional and contemporary performance routines. The group is actively seeking opportunities to perform in and around Berkeley, and could potentially compete in intercollegiat competitions. There are several collegiate Irish dance teams around the country. Seeing as UC Berkeley is one of the top universities in the world, we ought to have a group to represent the Bears when Irish dance groups meet up.

This art form is thriving in the Bay Area, and Cal should be connected to this Irish community. The Irish Dancers of Berkeley can and will serve as cultural ambassadors around campus, the Bay, and beyond.

Organization.Name: Japanese Graduates & Researchers Society at Berkeley
Organization.Description: To create an opportunity for Japanese graduate students and researchers to socialize and interact, to provide members with an environment for their academic and professional achievements, and to act as a link between the Campus, organizations interested in the activities of JGRS-Berkeley including almni and prospective students of UC Berkeley, and other Japanese societies in other campuses on the nation.

Organization.Name: JMed: The Jewish Pre-Medical Network at Berkeley

Organization.Description: Through hosting a variety of open admission events, Legends of Berkeley takes the culture of gaming and ensures that students with any interest have a place to create relationships, thus diversifying the quality of life at Berkeley.

Organization.Summary: This group aims to promote awareness of Middle Eastern culture and traditions with an emphasis on Middle Eastern Dance.
Organization.Description: We will focus on a variety of dance forms including but not limited to: Belly Dance, Persian Dance, and traditional Middle Eastern Folk Dance. Through workshops, performances, and social events this group hopes to convey the uniqueness of the Middle Eastern culture with UC Berkeley students and the community.

Organization.Name: OpenDialogues at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: OpenDialogues promotes personal growth by cultivating life stories through dialogue-centric mentorship.
Organization.Description:
We define OpenDialogues as mutually beneficial, uninhibited, non-prescriptive conversations built around various life themes. Through open dialogues, we can better develop our life story which propels us to attain greater personal growth and future achievements.

Our program is based on the notion that everyone is greatly impacted by our informal conversations -- we are enriched by actively engaging with each other. In OpenDialogues, each participant has a unique role to play, and each mentorship pair has unique stories to share. Our program is focused on facilitating this dynamic, through which we aim to shape life stories one open dialogue at a time.

Students and mentors are connected one-on-one to make a mentorship pair, with all pairs forming A Modern Mentorship Community.

Organization.Name: Optometry Class of 2017 at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The Optometry Class of 2017 at Berkeley is a student run organization whose purpose is to promote communication between optometry students, faculty, and the optometric professionals.
Organization.Description: This group aims to educate the community of current issues affecting the profession of optometry, and to fundraise for social and professional events, and community projects.

Organization.Description: We aim to educate students in the art of elocution and provide a unique environment to facilitate growth and improvement in public speaking, interview techniques, and debate abilities. We have planned interactive presentations, practice activities, and guest speakers.

Organization.Summary: Portraits of Kindness at Berkeley is a club through which students create portraits of orphans from around the world to honor their heritage, help build a positive self-esteem, and commemorate their childhood. Contact info is under "read more"!
Organization.Description:
Mission:

Our mission is to encourage UC Berkeley students to turn their artistic skills into something greater than simply art. Through our projects, we nurture the lives of orphans worldwide and inspire the Berkeley community to share kindness with those in need

Process:

Participants receive photos of orphans waiting for portraits and then work from those photos to create portraits (drawings, paintings, digital art). Next, the portraits are delivered to the orphans as gifts. Finally, each artist receives a photo of the rpahn holding his/her portrait! 

Intrested for more information or would like to join: 

Shoot us a message on facebook.com/PortraitsofKindness or email us at PortraitsOfKindness@gmail.com!

Our greater mission is to strengthen ties between high school and UC Berkeley students, and to promote high school students to pursue higher education.We publish literature and visual art by the Berkeley student community and report on recent artistic events and accomplishments at UC Berkeley. Our mission is to provide space for new writers and artists to have their work published. We want to form a community of creative people to share their ideas and gain exposure.

Organization.Summary: We educate and inform members on Social Media, Web 2.0 and Web 3.0, collaborate with other organizations to plan develop and implement Social Media Strategies and offer networking and job opportunities to current club members and alumnus
