Organization.Name: Society of Physics Students at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The Society of Physics Students is an organization dedicated to physics-related ideas and cutting-edge research.
Organization.Description: We encourage and assist students interested in physics to develop the knowledge, competence, enthusiasm, and social responsibility that are essential to the advancement of physics; stimulate interest in advanced study and research in physics; develop collegiality among physics students and faculty members; promote public interest in physics; and provide liaison between students and the member societies of the American Institute of Physics.

Organization.Name: South Asia Colloquium at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The South Asia Colloquium is a forum for students and faculty of various disciplines to discuss topics and particular works of research that concern the region of South Asia.

Organization.Name: Space Exploration Society at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The Space Exploration Society at Berkeley is the Berkeley chapter for Students for the Exploration and Development of Space (SEDS) and The Planetary Society (TPS). Our goal is to stimulate interest in a space-related career for students of all majors.
Organization.Description:
By inspiring the next generation of space scientists, we hope to accelerate the development and exploration of space. We will accomplish our goals by forming a network of students interested in space, providing leadership opportunities, educating both students and non-students with scientific outreach, participating in space-related competitions (rocket-building, 3D printing, space policy), and interacting with professional organizations and companies. 

The Space Exploration Society at Berkeley is the only club at Berkeley to promote the exploration and development of space. We serve as the de facto astronomy club at Berkeley since it is directly related to space interests.  We are also the first interdisciplinary society for encouraging space interests and soliciting members from all majors including engineering, the physical sciences, humanities, and all others.

Organization.Name: Student Global Health Alliance at Berkeley
Synesthesia Association at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Provides an open forum for people interested in exploring the phenomena of synesthesia, promoting awareness of cognitive diversity in the student community, allowing perspectives to be shared and explored that would not otherwise be discovered

Organization.Name: Triathlon Club at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The purpose of the Triathlon Club at Berkeley is to bring the sport of triathlon to the student community at the University of California, Berkeley and its surrounding environs.
Organization.Description: Triathlon is a multi-sport event consisting of swimming, biking, and running that offers a potential for lifelong enjoyment and passion. It is this lifestyle that the Triathlon Club at Berkeley seeks to bring to its members. Finally, this club hopes to represent a standard in the organization, competition, and applicability for collegiate triathlon clubs around the nation. We will bring the sport of triathlon to the aforementioned groups and entities through a combination of detailed education about all stages of the sport, offering organized practices, as well as a sharing of our resources. These resources include access to our monetary resources for organized team events, access to our sponsorships to make the sport more affordable, and access to the array of experience and knowledge about the sport accumulated by the members.

Organization.Name: UC Haiti Initiative at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The UC Haiti Initiative (UCHI) is a group of faculty, students, alumni, and several members of the administration dedicated mobilizing resources of the UC system for assistance in Haiti reconstruction.
Organization.Description: The UC Haiti Initiative (UCHI) is a group of faculty, students, alumni, and several members of the administration dedicated mobilizing resources of the UC system for assistance in Haiti reconstruction. We aim to form partnerships with Haitian academic counterparts, civil society organizations, NGOs, and Haitian Government agencies in a defined municipality to enhance capacity building through education and research. We will focus on six core areas: (1) Agriculture, (2) Arts History & Culture, (3) Economics & Law, (4) Education & Psychosocial Assistance, (5) Engineering Architecture & Technology, and (6) Health Care. All projects will emphasize initiative and direction by our Haitian partnering institutions and organizations to establish self-sustaining, long term mechanisms for continued development. We hope to build a community of students, faculty, and administration at UC Berkeley dedicated to long-term sustained development in Haiti.

Organization.Name: Association of Chinese Entrepreneurs at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Founded in early 2012, Association of Chinese Entrepreneurs (ACE) at Berkeley is the largest Chinese entrepreneurial community at UC Berkeley.
Organization.Description:
Founded in early 2012, Association of Chinese Entrepreneurs (ACE) at Berkeley is the largest Chinese entrepreneurial community at UC Berkeley. Our mission is to connect entrepreneurial individuals, consolidate entrepreneurship network, and incubate future industry leaders. We provide valuable learning and networking opportunities for our members through a wide range of entrepreneurship events/programs and extensive collaboration with other communities in US universities and Silicon Valley.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Environmental Economics and Policy Students
Organization.Summary: A UC Berkeley student organization for students of the Environmental Economics and Policy major and minor to network, socialize and prepare for post graduation.
Organization.Description:
BEEPS (Berkeley Environmental Economics and Policy Students) seeks to bring students of the EEP major together through conceptualizing, collaborating, networking, learning and socializing.
 
As a group of friends in the EEP major, we thought it would be fun to have a place where other EEP students could come and meet each other. This idea grew to not only include community building and socializing, but to provide resources for EEP majors to be better prepared for the professional world. These resources will include talks from professionals, alumni, professors, and graduate students, as well as software workshops and peer tutoring.

The plan is to hold general meetings every other week, where the officers bring in speakers (e.g. EEP alumni) to discuss their career paths and to answer our questions. Occasionally, we will hold review sessions, software workshops, and fun social events. We want to prepare ourselves for the future and have fun doing it!
 
Contact officers at calbeeps@gmail.com to get on the list serve or ask general questions.

Organization.Summary: Global Student Embassy at Berkeley looks to bring Cal students together with international communities in order to create positive, grassroots change on a local and multinational scale.

We believe that students are young ambassadors who can practice grassroots international relations by identifying local issues, collaborating with their global peers, and implementing projects that create positive change within the community. We currently have projects in Northern California, Nicaragua, and Ecuador building school gardens with a focus in biointensive agriculture. Our goal is to send Cal students to GSE's sister gardens in order to learn, through experience, about social and environmental justice as well as sustainable farming techniques.

Global Student Embassy is unique in that it seeks to create a dialogue across international borders on a wide range of issues including grassroots organizing, social justice, public health, environmental crises, and more. We are a diverse group of students and organizers interested in banding together in order to address problems that affect as all.

Organization.Name: Coaching Corps at Berkeley
Organization.Summary:
We improve the health, educational and social outcomes for kids living in struggling communities through the power of service and sports.
If you would like to coach check out: http://www.coachingcorps.org/coach/
Organization.Description:
We are a Corps of motivated college students and community members who serve as volunteer coaches, mentors and role models in afterschool sports programs serving girls and boys who live in some of our most under-resourced communities.

We exist to ensure that for all kids, the opportunity to run, play, learn, be coached and work with a team is a given – not a luxury. We are Coaching Corps and we are changing the game for the kids who need us most.

On the surface, what we do may look easy – we offer a full-season of sports programs for kids who normally wouldn’t get them.  We pair up with another Coaching Corps coach and we create teams, design drills, give high-fives and coach our kids through wins and losses on and off the field.

If you look deeper, we are more than just coaches.  We promote positive peer relationships, inspire leadership in kids and ensure the emotional and physical safety of all our athletes.  We know there is no life lesson that sports can’t teach … and we teach those lessons.

To date, 3,000 of us have changed the game for more than 30,000 kids.

Additionally, we offer our afterschool partners a range of crucial support, including training and consulting.

We are a community of advocates. Through our research and special initiatives, we raise awareness of the disparity in opportunity for populations most in need such as girls in low-income communities. And we educate policymakers and opinion leaders on the importance of ensuring that all kids have a chance to play – and experience the life-changing benefits of sports.

We have embarked on an ambitious goal to change the game for 300,000 kids across the nation over the next five years.

Organization.Name: College Track's Success Team at Berkeley
Corporate Finance at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Interact with corporate finance professionals through educational presentations Develop critical understanding of the profession Reach out networking opportunities & meet new friends with mutual goals and interests Engage in targeting job opportunities
Organization.Description:
While UC Berkeley encompasses many business-related clubs with concentrations on areas such as consulting, marketing, and investment banking; there does not exist a club focused on the topic of corporate finance.

We aim to prepare our members with the confidence and skills to begin fulfilling careers in corporate finance, an emerging field with rapidly growing interest. Corporate finance involves helping firms make financial decisions by analyzing sources of funding and the capital structure of corporations, with the aim of increasing the firms’ value to shareholders. There has been an increasing amount of interest in corporate financing, and many potential employers visit UC Berkeley each year to recruit qualified students with intended careers in corporate finance. Our club will serve as the intermediate between interested students and their intended jobs or internships by preparing them from the ground up with career exploration, resume critique, and mock interviews.

In addition, we will provide our members with practice and real experience in corporate finance. We will invite finance companies to Berkeley and give our members case competitions for training. We will also invite professionals with knowledge and experience in corporate finance to advice club members in preparation for both case competitions and potential interviews. Finally, we will teach essential skills to members – the valuation of firms and basic company analysis – through inviting professors and MBA students as guest speakers.

Organization.Description:
Our mission: to (1) introduce people to the sport of curling and (2) compete in weekly recreational curling matches.

We are the first collegiate curling club in the state of California, and members have the opportunity to help other colleges and universities start clubs to foster intercollegiate competition. Our long-term goal is to field teams at the US National College Curling Championship.

We're partnered with the San Francisco Bay Area Curling Club, and we curl at the Oakland Ice Center, which is accessible by both BART and AC Transit bus. To access by BART, take the Fremont-bound line to 19th St. Oakland station and exit via Telegraph Ave. To access by AC Transit bus, take the 1 bus toward Bay Fair BART and alight at the 19th St. Oakland BART stop.

If you're interested in learning more about curling, get started here! Also, check out this introduction video from the US Curling Association!

Be sure to follow us on Facebook and Twitter! And for questions on events or curling in general, email us at calcurling@gmail.com!

Generation Citizen at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Generation Citizen envisions a democracy in which every citizen participates. We strengthen our nations democracy by empowering young people to become engaged and effective citizens, starting now.
Organization.Description:
Generation Citizen envisions a democracy in which every citizen participates. We strengthen our nation’s democracy by empowering young people to become engaged and effective citizens, starting now.  We partner college student Democracy Coaches with classroom teachers to teach an action civics course in which teens solve problems they are facing in their own communities. 

 

Club is ran in the form of a DeCal:

DeCal will be one of the requirements for participation in Generation Citizen at Cal. Students commit to attending and participating in the DeCal seminars as well as the classroom meetings at an assigned middle or high school in Berkeley, Oakland or Richmond. The DeCal serves as a seminar where the Democracy Coaches will receive ongoing support, ask questions, plan lessons, share the experiences they have with their middle- or high-school class.

 

Throughout this course, we will learn about local political structures, classroom management tips and strategies for student motivation and engagement. We will also discuss the previous and upcoming weeks’ classroom outcomes, and strategies for increasing the presence of Generation Citizen at UC Berkeley.

Organization.Name: International Service Learning at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: International Service Learning (ISL) is a nonprofit organization that offers health services to underserved populations around the world. Our Berkeley chapter recruits students for medical/pharmacy, dental, and optometry trips.
Organization.Description:
About

International Service Learning (ISL) is a nonprofit organization that has sent thousands of students all over the world to volunteer in underserved communities. For the 2013-14 academic year, our Berkeley chapter will recruit students for medical/pharmacy, dental, and optometry teams. Our primary teams will travel to Central America during Cal's Spring Break. We will also be supporting smaller teams interested in traveling together during Winter Break. Before the trips, we will hold workshops to learn about the diagnosis and treatment of common health problems, medical Spanish, and basic techniques relating to your field. We also plan to fundraise to help subsidize the cost of the trip and collect donated supplies and medications.

This is a really great experience for anyone interested in the health field, as you will gain hands-on experience while helping communities that lack access to healthcare and resources necessary for their basic well-being. You will work closely with health professionals and interact directly with patients, while also having a ton of fun with your peers! Keep a lookout for our recruitment info sessions towards the middle of the Fall Semester.

If you have any questions or you'd like to join our mailing list, plese email islatberkeley@gmail.com.

Please read on for further details about the teams and how to get involved!

 

How to Apply

We recruit members for our Spring Break teams towards the middle of the Fall Semester. Keep an eye out for our infosession announcements. After the infosession(s), an application form will be sent out to everyone who attended and everyone on our mailing list. This application will be due approximately a week later. We will let you know if you have been accepted into one of our teams before the Thanksgiving weekend. After you hear from us, you must sign up on ISL’s official website: http://www.islonline.org/

 

Medical/Pharmacy Team - Sample Trip Activities

PRACTICAL MEDICAL SEMINAR

The day after our arrival, we had an all-day seminar to prepare ourselves for the work we would be doing at our mobile clinic. Two local doctors, assisted by our official ISL team leader, led the seminar. First we did an overview of various ailments that we would likely encounter at our mobile clinic, such as urinary tract infections, COPD, and gastrointestinal worms. The information given emphasized the symptoms of the ailments, and this was very helpful for us later when we were diagnosing patients at our mobile clinic. In addition, we were given extensive handouts on the various medications that could be given to treat the ailments. These handouts included dosage information for children versus adults, which was also very useful during our mobile clinics.

The second part of the seminar emphasized practical skills. We were given step-by-step instructions on how to efficiently perform triage. During this portion of the seminar, we were instructed on the proper use of stethoscopes, blood pressure cuffs, glucometers, and urine test strips. We were also taught various ways of using our sense of hearing and our sense of touch to identify potential ailments in a patient. Having the opportunity to practice these skills on our teammates greatly increased our confidence and efficiency during our mobile clinic.

Lastly, the medical seminar covered some basic medical Spanish, in addition to general patient interaction skills. While it is not necessary to speak Spanish to go on the trip (ISL provides excellent translators), we all felt closer to our patients when we were able to ask them simple questions like, “¿Cómo está usted?” and “¿Dónde le duele?”

HOUSE VISITS TO THE COMMUNITY

The next day, we visited the village where we would later be setting up our mobile clinic. In groups of 3 or 4, we went door-to-door with a local ISL guide asking members of the community about their living and health conditions. Besides taking the opportunity to advertise for our mobile clinic, the public health data we gathered would later be analyzed by ISL to determine some of the overarching health trends in the community, which they could use to improve their mobile clinics. It was a very eye-opening experience to see the homes and lifestyles of the local people. It was interesting to observe how the houses grew noticeably less well-built the further we moved from the town center, how many families used wood as their primary fuel for cooking, how important a bicycle could be for transportation, and how infrequently many individuals saw a doctor or other health professional. The villagers were exceptionally kind and welcoming. All in all it was a very rewarding experience.

MOBILE CLINIC

On the following three days of our trip we worked at a mobile clinic that we set up in the village of La Concha. There, we set up stations where groups of 4 students and one ISL translator would see patients. Two doctors oversaw the groups and a couple of students manned a pharmacy table where patients would go after they were seen by one of the groups. In each group, students took turns doing triage. We measured the height and weight of the patients, took their blood pressure, and depending on what they came in for, we also measured their blood glucose levels and analyzed urine samples. We were given standardized intake sheets for the patients where we could record such information in addition to age, family health history, etc. This mobile clinic served as a great learning experience for students, as we were allowed to practice diagnosing and prescribing treatments for the patients. Afterwards, one of the doctors would come and correct us if we had made any errors.

We saw a variety of patients. For example, there was a child with gastrointestinal worms, a man whose painful abdominal hernia prevented him from working, and several women with vaginal and urinary tract infections. For some of the patients, such as the women with urinary tract infections, we were easily able to come up with a diagnosis and we knew exactly which medications to prescribe. However, there were other patients for whom we could do nothing. We were not able to give the man with the hernia anything except painkillers, because we lacked the manpower and equipment to give him the surgery he needed. In addition, each morning over 80 people would be lined up in front of our clinic before we even arrived, and over the course of our working day we would barely be able to see half of them. The experience of both successfully helping someone and being unable to help others was the most inspiring part of the ISL experience for me.

HOSPITAL VISIT

One afternoon we visited a local hospital. It was very interesting to observe how the hospital functioned. Our local ISL representative explained how the hospital was understaffed, so only patients who are very sick but who the doctors believe they have a good chance of curing get admitted. Most of these admitted patients get put up in beds in the hospital’s main sickroom. This sickroom was a long, corridor-like room with slightly over a dozen beds lined along one wall. When we visited the hospital, we helped the nurses take blood pressure, blood sugar levels, etc. of the patients in the sickroom. In addition, we were able to observe several surgeries that were scheduled during our visit. Unlike in an American hospital, we were able to stand inside one of the hospital’s two operating theaters to observe surgery. The most common surgeries are C-sections.

RECREATIONAL

Our trip also featured plenty of recreational activities. For example, we visited an active volcano, a political prison, a zip-lining park, and a market fair. One of the highlights of the trip was a visit to a local elementary school. Beforehand, we went shopping for toys to give to the children. At the school we played games with the children (including batting a piñata!) and gave them the toys as prizes. Lastly, the food throughout the trip was amazing, and our hotel was very quaint. There was ample time at the hotel to bond with fellow ISL teammates or get some homework done.

 

Dental Team Activities

DENTAL EDUCATION SEMINAR 

The first full day of the trip, we were visited by one of the dentists who would be working with us for the week. She had brought with her a large assortment of dental equipment as well as a powerpoint presentation of what we will be going over during the next few days. Of course, we had been prepped with the information prior to coming to Nicaragua but going over the information was a lot more reassuring. We went over dental procedures (extractions, fillings, cleanings), dental tools (mirror, explorer, elevators, condensers and etc), dental issues (plaque build up and current oral health issues) as well as Spanish dental terminology! Afterwards she went over a general idea of what we were going to do over the week.

PATIENT RECRUITMENT

The next day, we arrived at a small village which was located next to the temporary clinic that we would be working at. In small groups, we were split in pairs with a dentist (also our translator/guide) who took us around the village to recruit all the patients we would be treating over the next few days. Door to door, we went around doing basic check-ups (looking for severity and urgency of dental care) and asked a quick survey of questions regarding dental and oral health. Then we gave them a small presentation on oral care and small tips that they should keep in mind regarding oral health. There was definitely plenty of experience on trying what little Spanish we learned from before or during the trip. Once we made appointments to those who needed care, we moved to the next house. Most were gracious and gave us mangos, star fruits and other amazing delights!

CLINIC WORK DAYS

These are the days that everyone was looking forward to. We had our equipment and we had the patients; all we needed was to get some dental work done! The morning of, we arrived at the church that lent their space for us to work at and set up a temporary dental clinic. We had chairs, sterilizing and dental equipment donated to us through ISL and a local Dental School so setting up was a good learning experience. The chairs were set, the dental tools were placed on a large long table in the middle and the sterilizing equipment was placed towards the back.

I will have to say, the next part of the trip was such a rewarding time. The dental experience is indispensable. Each dentist was paired with two of us and we were given the opportunity to assist in every procedure. As patients were seated in the chair, the dentist did an exam and assessed what the patient needed most. Having been prepped with dental procedures we then proceeded to pick out the instruments we needed for the patient. Next to the patient, we took part in fillings, extractions and cleanings. Of course, with enough practice, we were sometimes asked to help more. It was by far the most engaging dental-related activity I had ever done.

It took most of us a while to learn how to handle the tools and equipment at first but with real patients, it was just amazing to see how fast we learned. It was just the rawest experience that any one of us would get and soon, we were adept with our tasks that we were doing things even without the dentist having to ask us. By the end of the day, things just seemed natural. Day after day, we were getting better and more efficient. Each patient was different and even with the same procedures; it always felt different and new. Things never got boring.

RECREATIONAL

Every day, as much work we put in, we were having as much fun. Our guide took us to amazing restaurants (truly unforgettable), active volcano sites, bat caves, and even cultural shows! There was seriously just so much that we were always doing something. Even in our free time back in our hotel, we were busy eating mangos that just naturally seemed to grow everywhere and meeting people every day. I still often think back to the nice weather that simply enveloped your skin while I gazed at the lovely skies on a rocking chair with a juicy mango in my hand.

 

Optometry Overview

The Optometry Team will get to work alongside optometrists, perform eye exams, examine common eye problems in underserved communities of the country, and learn to use optometric Spanish to interact with patients. 

BASIC EYE EXAM

  • Basic Eye Health Assessment and Screening Exam
  • Visual Acuity Assessment
  • Screening/measurement for possible refractive errors
  • Measuring Near/Distance Vision
  • Pinhole Occluder Testing
  • Screening for Binocular Dysfunction (Cover / Uncover Test)
  • Screening for Coordinated Eye Movement (Versions Test)
  • Screening for Limitations of Visual Field
  • Screening Color Vision
  • Measuring Pupillary Distance (PD)

EYE DISEASES/TROPICAL EYE PROBLEMS

  • Screening for Acanthosis Nigricans
  • Pterygium screening
  • Problems caused by living conditions/lifestyle
  • Excessive UV exposure
  • Frequent contact with smoke and dust

 EDUCATION/REFERRALS

  • Interviewing the Patient and suggesting preventive practices
  • Giving Eye Health and Safety Information
  • Information on hygiene, nutrition, UV protection, and injury
  • Referring patients to eye care professionals based on certain criteria

EQUIPMENT

  • Supervised use of ophthalmoscope and retinoscope

Organization.Name: Investment Banking Student Association of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The Investment Banking Student Association of Berkeley is one of the first clubs at Berkeley that focuses on all aspects of revenue-generating operations at a bulge bracket investment bank. We prepare members for summer analyst roles at investment banks.
Organization.Description: This organization consists of members having previously worked or planning to work at an investment bank. We have a focus on practical experience and training will consist of including financial modeling, valuation, and accounting courses taught by students and professionals having worked or who are currently working in the field. We also plan to partner with firms to hold externships at their offices, and hold investment banking case competitions on campus. Instead of being a club of purely interest in investment banking and focusing on following industry news, we differentiate ourselves by providing members significant practical case, modeling, and work experience. We only accept members who are serious about investment banking as a career path, as we will utilize our resources to help them secure a job in the field to the very best of our ability.

Organization.Name: Jehovah's Witness at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The purpose of Jehovah's Witnesses at Berkeley is one of Bible education and distribution of Bible-based literature.

Organization.Name: Judo Appreciation Club of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: To analyze and practice the goals and philosophy of the Japanese martial art, Judo, as intended by its founder, Kano Jigoro, and his many disciples.

Organization.Name: League of Legends Group at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: League of Legends Group at Berkeley is an organization for fans of the popular game League of Legends. The club hosts League related events, such as tournaments, LAN gatherings, screenings of professional matches, as well as representing Berkeley.

Organization.Name: Learning Enterprises at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The purpose of this organization is to start a new, active campus of the non-profit organization Learning Enterprises. This organization sends volunteers to several countries around the world to teach English.
Organization.Description:
The organization will adopt LE’s mission and goals, which are stated on the website: www.learningenterprises.org as “(1) fostering creativity, (2) using the English language as a means of communication, (3) cross-cultural exchange, (4) spreading the spirit of volunteerism, and (5) providing substantive and rewarding work experience for young people”. The goals of this organization specifically will be to spread the word about LE, recruit applicants from our campus, provide support for applicants who are chosen, and ultimately send successful student volunteers around the world to teach English. There will also be a focus on fundraising for the organization LE as a whole, as well as for our individual LE campus.

Learning Enterprises is an incredible non-profit organization that sends young volunteers to teach English abroad during the summer. This organization will aim to recruit students to apply to an LE program abroad (we have over 10 programs for this coming summer). After interviewing with the Campus Director (Neha Shah, the founder of this organization at Berkeley) and the Program Director (the director of the program to which the student is applying), volunteers will be selected. This organization will then train the selected volunteers on the ways of successfully teaching ESL in a different country. This training will include discussions on creating a curriculum for a summer of teaching, how a volunteer can provide additional services to his/her community (for example a service project at a volunteer's school), and how to adjust to living with a host family and experiencing a cultural immersion. On the whole, this organization wants to spread the word about LE and give students at Berkeley an opportunity to volunteer abroad in a school where English teachers are needed. The organization will also work to fundraise for LE as a whole and for the Berkeley subdivision of LE.

Organization.Name: Multimedia Orchestra @Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The goal of the Berkeley Multimedia Orchestra is to leverage the abundance of technical and artistic talent at UC Berkeley to create works and installations mediated by interactive and innovative technology.

Organization.Name: New Church Berkeley College Life
Organization.Summary: To provide a connection to a local church (New Church Berkeley) for students interested in pursuing the spiritual side of life, especially the teaching and person of Jesus Christ

Organization.Name: Pennies for Patients Committee at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: This committee will bring the Pennies for Patients project to the campus. Through classroom presentations, posters around campus, and seminars, we hope to collect funds in specially marked boxes to donate to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.
Organization.Description: Our proposed organization is unique because we are dedicated to just the Pennies for Patients project that has not been introduced to the UC Berkeley campus yet. We believe that having such a specific focus will allow us to put in all our efforts into raising funds for the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, an organization committed to cure several blood cancers, raise cancer awareness, and improve the quality of life of patients and their families. We also hope to develop empathy and respect for all people who struggle with these forms of cancer.

Activities:

Sound good? Email pokemonclubatcal@gmail.com to be added to a mailing list for further information on meetings and events!

Organization.Name: Psychology at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: A scientific publication specializing in undergraduate research conducted in psychology and related fields.
Organization.Description: The Undergraduate Journal of Psychology at Berkeley (UJPB) is a student-run publication which features exciting research from undergraduates in the areas of psychology, neuroscience, cognitive science, and other related fields. We feature articles by authors from all over the country, providing a great way for undergrads to get a sense of what their peers are up to and bring the community of undergraduate research a little closer together.

Organization.Description: We hope to provide an outlet by which camaraderie, social gatherings, public services, and other such benefits may be met through the united enjoyment of such aforementioned works

Organization.Name: Ski and Snowboard Team at Berkeley
Social Ballroom Dance Club at Berkeley
Stock Trading Crew of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The Stock Trading Crew of Berkeley brings anyone who is interested in trading stocks on a short term time frame together. We do NOT invest in stocks. We trade stocks that have great technicals and positive future catalysts.
Organization.Description: We plan to work together, sharing and debating about ideas, using technical, fundamental, and derivatives analysis to generate the greatest return possible in a short period of time with minimal risk. We do NOT “invest” in stocks. We simply “trade” stocks that have great technicals and positive future catalysts that will propel the stock forward in only a couple weeks or months. Members will learn and trade (paper trade or trade with their own real accounts if experienced) alongside with other members during the day, utilizing the three types of analyses described above. Members will meet either in person or online in a proposed chatroom between the hours of 6:30am-1pm from Monday thru Friday - whenever members have the time to do so.

Organization.Name: Students for Free Culture at Berkeley
Students Supporting Doctors Without Borders at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: In direct support of the international Doctors Without Borders organization, we work with developing communities that are threatened by violence, neglect, or catastrophe to improve their quality of life through ensuring greater access to medical aid.
Organization.Description: The UC Berkeley Chapter of Doctors Without Borders, in direct support of the international Médecins Sans Frontières/Doctors Without Borders organization, works with developing communities that are threatened by violence, neglect, or catastrophe to improve their quality of life though ensuring greater access to medical aid. Through direct service, education, and collaboration with various parties, DWB aims to engage UC Berkeley students in a growing movement for global health. Furthermore, DWB aspires to instill a lasting responsibility and commitment to global health among members of the Cal community and empower pre-medical students to carry out this commitment in their personal and professional lives as prospective medical doctors.

Organization.Name: Swipes for the Homeless at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Swipes for the Homeless aims to tangibly and tactically partner with college campuses to alleviate hunger while raising college students awareness of homelessness and hunger, which is prevalent in their community, through education and outreach.
Organization.Description: Swipes for the Homeless is an international, 501(c)3 non-profit organization consisting of a coalition of university and college chapters located throughout the world. Their dual mission is to tangibly and tactically partner with college campuses to alleviate hunger while raising college students’ awareness of homelessness and hunger, which is prevalent in their community, through education and outreach. Swipes for the Homeless was established as a student organization in the Fall of 2009 at the University of California, Los Angeles.  The organization has now established successful chapters at University of Southern California, University of Paris in France, University of California, Santa Barbara, University of California at Irvine, and University of California at San Diego. Ultimately, Swipes for the Homeless is a broad-based collaborative initiative among university students who are assisting in alleviating the neighboring homeless populations through programs and events among university communities, in hopes of eventually impeding hunger and homelessness.

Organization.Name: Team F.I.T. at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Team F.I.T. is a coalition whose purpose is to forge stronger spirits by promoting healthy living of both body and mind, achieved through the application of three core values: Fitness, Integrity, and Teamwork.
